description.en: Information (e.g. e-mail address, telephone number) of a person or department through which the user can get in touch with.

usage.en: The Core Public Organization Vocabulary defines properties for telephone number, e-mail address and opening hours although it is noteworthy that the class is based on schema.org's ContactPoint class that has additional properties that some implementations may find useful.

rawTags.definition-en: Information (e.g. e-mail address, telephone number) of a person or department through which the user can get in touch with.
rawTags.usageNote-en: The Core Public Organization Vocabulary defines properties for telephone number, e-mail address and opening hours although it is noteworthy that the class is based on schema.org's ContactPoint class that has additional properties that some implementations may find useful.

description.en: A web page that could be used to reach out the Contact Point.

rawTags.definition-en: A web page that could be used to reach out the Contact Point.

description.en: An electronic address through which the Contact Point can be contacted.

rawTags.definition-en: An electronic address through which the Contact Point can be contacted.

description.en: A telephone number through which the Contact Point can be contacted.

rawTags.definition-en: A telephone number through which the Contact Point can be contacted.

description.en: The time at which the Contact Point is normally available.

rawTags.definition-en: The time at which the Contact Point is normally available.

description.en: The time during which the Contact Point is not available.

rawTags.definition-en: The time during which the Contact Point is not available.

description.en: A logo to describe / represent an entity.

rawTags.definition-en: A logo to describe / represent an entity.

description.en: An Organization that is defined as being part of the public sector by a legal framework at any level.

usage.en:
Organizations which exist to provide services for its citizens and companies are called Public Organizations. The Public Organization class represents the organization. One organization may comprise several sub-organizations and any organization may have one or more organizational units. Each of these is described using the same properties and relationships.

This definition is consistent with the more detailed definition of a "public sector body" as given in the PSI Directive: "the State, regional or local authorities, bodies governed by public law and associations formed by one or several such authorities or one or several such bodies governed by public law". It further defines a body governed by public law as any body "(a) established for the specific purpose of meeting needs in the general interest, not having an industrial or commercial character; and (b) having legal personality; and (c) financed, for the most part by the State, or regional or local authorities, or other bodies governed by public law; or subject to management supervision by those bodies; or having an administrative, managerial or supervisory board, more than half of whose members are appointed by the State, regional or local authorities or by other bodies governed by public law".

rawTags.definition-en: An Organization that is defined as being part of the public sector by a legal framework at any level.
rawTags.usageNote-en:
Organizations which exist to provide services for its citizens and companies are called Public Organizations. The Public Organization class represents the organization. One organization may comprise several sub-organizations and any organization may have one or more organizational units. Each of these is described using the same properties and relationships.

This definition is consistent with the more detailed definition of a "public sector body" as given in the PSI Directive: "the State, regional or local authorities, bodies governed by public law and associations formed by one or several such authorities or one or several such bodies governed by public law". It further defines a body governed by public law as any body "(a) established for the specific purpose of meeting needs in the general interest, not having an industrial or commercial character; and (b) having legal personality; and (c) financed, for the most part by the State, or regional or local authorities, or other bodies governed by public law; or subject to management supervision by those bodies; or having an administrative, managerial or supervisory board, more than half of whose members are appointed by the State, regional or local authorities or by other bodies governed by public law".

description.en: The main contact information of the resource.

usage.en: Usually a phone number and e-mail address. Other contact methods may be included, including online contact information, but this is conceptually distinct from the organization's homepage that may or may not provide contact information.

rawTags.definition-en: The main contact information of the resource.
rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=Usually a phone number and e-mail address. Other contact methods may be included, including online contact information, but this is conceptually distinct from the organization's homepage that may or may not provide contact information.

description.en: A graphic symbol to represent the Public Organization.

usage.en: The value of this property can simply be the URL of the logo but it is better for developers if it links to an object that provides the URL of the image and essential metadata about it, notably its dimensions.

rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The value of this property can simply be the URL of the logo but it is better for developers if it links to an object that provides the URL of the image and essential metadata about it, notably its dimensions.
rawTags.definition-en: A graphic symbol to represent the Public Organization.

description.en: The textual description of the Public Organization.

rawTags.definition-en: The textual description of the Public Organization.

description.en: This property links an Organization to the Administrative Region(s) that it covers.

usage.en:
The value of the properly should be the URI of the region as defined in an authoritative list of regions. In Europe, this is likely to be the Administrative Territorial Units Named Authority List maintained by the Publications Office's Metadata Registry.

The ATU list does not include a geometry. That is, the territory is only identified by its name not its spatial coordinates. This is likely to be the case for similar lists. If geometries are available for the Public Organization's territory, they can be linked from the territorial unit using the Core Location Vocabulary's locn:geometry property.

rawTags.ap-usageNote-en:
The value of the properly should be the URI of the region as defined in an authoritative list of regions. In Europe, this is likely to be the Administrative Territorial Units Named Authority List maintained by the Publications Office's Metadata Registry.

The ATU list does not include a geometry. That is, the territory is only identified by its name not its spatial coordinates. This is likely to be the case for similar lists. If geometries are available for the Public Organization's territory, they can be linked from the territorial unit using the Core Location Vocabulary's locn:geometry property.
rawTags.ap-definition-en: This property links an Organization to the Administrative Region(s) that it covers.

description.en: In some cases, it is necessary to be able to create an ordered sequence of organizations that precede and succeed each other. To support this, the CPOV includes the well-known relationships of previous and next to allow such sequences to be captured and computed.

usage.en: Examples of events leading to sequences could be renaming, splitting or merging of public organizations.

rawTags.usageNote-en: Examples of events leading to sequences could be renaming, splitting or merging of public organizations.
rawTags.definition-en: In some cases, it is necessary to be able to create an ordered sequence of organizations that precede and succeed each other. To support this, the CPOV includes the well-known relationships of previous and next to allow such sequences to be captured and computed.

description.en: In some cases, it is necessary to be able to create an ordered sequence of an organization that precede and succeed each other. To support this, the CPOV includes the well-known relationships of previous and next to allow such sequences to be captured and computed.

usage.en: Examples of events leading to sequences could be renaming, splitting or merging of public organizations.

rawTags.definition-en: In some cases, it is necessary to be able to create an ordered sequence of an organization that precede and succeed each other. To support this, the CPOV includes the well-known relationships of previous and next to allow such sequences to be captured and computed.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Examples of events leading to sequences could be renaming, splitting or merging of public organizations.

description.en: An alternative or informal name(s) of a Public Organization, irrespective of language.

rawTags.definition-en: An alternative or informal name(s) of a Public Organization, irrespective of language.

description.en: A preferred label is used to provide the primary, legally recognised name of the Public Organization, as defined in the ORG Ontology.

usage.en: Refers to the official or legal name of a Public Organization. An organization may only have one such name in any given language. Primary names may be provided in multiple languages with multiple instances of the preferred label property.

rawTags.definition-en: A preferred label is used to provide the primary, legally recognised name of the Public Organization, as defined in the ORG Ontology.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Refers to the official or legal name of a Public Organization. An organization may only have one such name in any given language. Primary names may be provided in multiple languages with multiple instances of the preferred label property.

description.en: The unambiguous structured reference for the Public Organization.

usage.en: Public organizations identifiers are often using (but not limited to) acronyms. For example, among the EU institutions, the ECB is the identifier for the European Central Bank, OLAF for the European Anti-Fraud Office, and so on. These are formally recognised by the European Commission which provides a list of such acronyms.

rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=Public organizations identifiers are often using (but not limited to) acronyms. For example, among the EU institutions, the ECB is the identifier for the European Central Bank, OLAF for the European Anti-Fraud Office, and so on. These are formally recognised by the European Commission which provides a list of such acronyms.
rawTags.definition-en: The unambiguous structured reference for the Public Organization.

description.en: The Address of a Public Organization.

usage.en: For consistency with INSPIRE, the Location Core Vocabulary's Address class should be used.

rawTags.usageNote-en: For consistency with INSPIRE, the Location Core Vocabulary's Address class should be used.
rawTags.definition-en: The Address of a Public Organization.

description.en: The Change Event that changed the Organization.

usage.en: Usually a change in the legal framework that is linked with the existence and operation of the organisation.

rawTags.definition-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The Change Event that changed the Organization.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Usually a change in the legal framework that is linked with the existence and operation of the organisation.

description.en: The categorisation of the Public Organization.

usage.en: As an example, the Publications Office of the European Union provides a Named Authority list of Organization Types which is appropriate for European institutions. Other classification schemes should be used at other levels of Public Organization.

rawTags.definition-en: The categorisation of the Public Organization.
rawTags.usageNote-en: As an example, the Publications Office of the European Union provides a Named Authority list of Organization Types which is appropriate for European institutions. Other classification schemes should be used at other levels of Public Organization.

description.en: An Organization which is a member of another without being a sub organization, they are independent entities.

usage.en: The memberOf and hasMember properties are very simple and don't support statements describing the nature of the membership. The W3C Organization Ontology provides both this simple method and a more sophisticated model that does make it possible to, for example, provide information about the period of time in which one Organization was a member of another, the level of membership etc. That more sophisticated model should be used where necessary and may be used in addition to the simple memberOf/hasMember properties. An example of memberships are the EU member states and other partners which could be represented via different legal entities as members of EFSA, the European Food Safety Agency.

rawTags.definition-en: An Organization which is a member of another without being a sub organization, they are independent entities.
rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The memberOf and hasMember properties are very simple and don't support statements describing the nature of the membership. The W3C Organization Ontology provides both this simple method and a more sophisticated model that does make it possible to, for example, provide information about the period of time in which one Organization was a member of another, the level of membership etc. That more sophisticated model should be used where necessary and may be used in addition to the simple memberOf/hasMember properties. An example of memberships are the EU member states and other partners which could be represented via different legal entities as members of EFSA, the European Food Safety Agency.

description.en: An operational department within the Public Organization.

usage.en: Organizations typically comprise many departments, units, teams etc. Each of these is modelled in the CPOV as a unit that is linked from the parent Organization with hasUnit and to the parent with unitOf.

rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=Organizations typically comprise many departments, units, teams etc. Each of these is modelled in the CPOV as a unit that is linked from the parent Organization with hasUnit and to the parent with unitOf.
rawTags.definition-en: NOTE$ea_notes=An operational department within the Public Organization.

description.en: An Organization of which the Public Organisation is a member without being a sub organization, they are independent entities.

usage.en: The memberOf and hasMember properties are very simple and don't support statements describing the nature of the membership. The W3C Organization Ontology provides both this simple method and a more sophisticated model that does make it possible to, for example, provide information about the period of time in which one Organization was a member of another, the level of membership etc. That more sophisticated model should be used where necessary and may be used in addition to the simple memberOf/hasMember properties. An example of memberships are the EU member states and other partners which could be represented via different legal entities as members of EFSA, the European Food Safety Agency.

An example of memberships are the EU member states and other partners which could be represented via different legal entities as members of EFSA, the European Food Safety Agency.
rawTags.definition-en: An Organization of which the Public Organisation is a member without being a sub organization, they are independent entities.

description.en: This property describes the reasons of existence of an Organization.

usage.en: The ORG ontology suggests that this property can also be thought of as meaning 'remit' or 'responsibility.' Ideally this will link to a COFOG code but where this isn't possible or appropriate, other controlled vocabularies may be used.

rawTags.definition-en: This property describes the reasons of existence of an Organization.
rawTags.usageNote-en: The ORG ontology suggests that this property can also be thought of as meaning 'remit' or 'responsibility.' Ideally this will link to a COFOG code but where this isn't possible or appropriate, other controlled vocabularies may be used.

description.en: A Change Event from which the Public Organisation resulted.

usage.en: Usually a change in the legal framework that is linked with the existence and operation of the organisation.

rawTags.definition-en: A Change Event from which the Public Organisation resulted.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Usually a change in the legal framework that is linked with the existence and operation of the organisation.

description.en: The official home page of the Public Organization.

usage.en: The value of this property is a URL irrespective of the serialisation of the data.

rawTags.definition-en: The official home page of the Public Organization.
rawTags.usageNote-en: The value of this property is a URL irrespective of the serialisation of the data.

description.en: Legislation or official policy from which Requirements are derived.

usage.en: Usual Reference Frameworks are legal and non-legal specifications. Examples include procedures, tendering legislation, etc.

rawTags.definition-en: Legislation or official policy from which Requirements are derived.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Usual Reference Frameworks are legal and non-legal specifications. Examples include procedures, tendering legislation, etc.

rawTags.definition-en: An unambiguous reference to a Reference Framework.

description.en: A Change Event linked to relevant legislation or policy documents.

usage.en: An example is the reference framework under which the Change Event is defined.

rawTags.usageNote-en: An example is the reference framework under which the Change Event is defined.

description.en: A temporal interval or instant.

rawTags.definition-en: A temporal interval or instant.

description.en: The recurrence of an instant or period.

usage.en: It is recommended to use the frequency from an existing vocabulary like the Frequency from the Publications Office.

rawTags.definition: The recurrence of an instant or period.
rawTags.usageNote-en: It is recommended to use the frequency from an existing vocabulary like the Frequency from the Publications Office.

description.en: A  textual representation of the Temporal Entity.

rawTags.definition-en: A  textual representation of the Temporal Entity.

description.en: A structured reference that identifies an entity.

usage.en: The Identifier class is based on the UN/CEFACT class of the same name and is defined under the ADMS namespace.

rawTags.definition-en: A structured reference that identifies an entity.
rawTags.usageNote-en: The Identifier class is based on the UN/CEFACT class of the same name and is defined under the ADMS namespace.

description.en: URI of the scheme used to construct the identifier.

rawTags.definition-en: URI of the scheme used to construct the identifier.

description.en: The date on which the Identifier was assigned.

rawTags.definition-en: The date on which the Identifier was assigned.

description.en: Name of the scheme used to construct the identifier.

rawTags.definition-en: Name of the scheme used to construct the identifier.

description.en: A string of characters to uniquely identify a concept.

rawTags.definition-en: A string of characters to uniquely identify a concept.

description.en: The name of the agency that issued the identifier.

rawTags.definition-en: The name of the agency that issued the identifier.

description.en: A spatial object that in a human-readable way identifies a fixed location.

usage.en:
An "address representation" as conceptually defined by the INSPIRE Address Representation data type: "Representation of an address spatial object for use in external application schemas that need to include the basic, address information in a readable way.".

The representation of Addresses varies widely from one country's postal system to another. Even within countries, there are almost always examples of Addresses that do not conform to the stated national standard. However, ISO 19160-1 provides a method through which different Addresses can be converted from one conceptual model to another.

This specification was heavily based on the INSPIRE Address Representation data type. It is noteworthy that if an Address is provided using the detailed breakdown suggested by the properties for this class, then it will be INSPIRE-conformant. To this very granular set of properties, we add two further properties:

- full address (the complete address as a formatted string)
- addressID (a unique identifier for the address).

The first of these allows publishers to simply provide the complete Address as one string, with or without formatting. This is analogous to vCard's label property.

The addressID is part of the INSPIRE guidelines and provides a hook that can be used to link the Address to an alternative representation, such as vCard or OASIS xAL.

This class belongs to Core Location Vocabulary

rawTags.definition-en: A spatial object that in a human-readable way identifies a fixed location.
rawTags.usageNote-en:
An "address representation" as conceptually defined by the INSPIRE Address Representation data type: "Representation of an address spatial object for use in external application schemas that need to include the basic, address information in a readable way.".

The representation of Addresses varies widely from one country's postal system to another. Even within countries, there are almost always examples of Addresses that do not conform to the stated national standard. However, ISO 19160-1 provides a method through which different Addresses can be converted from one conceptual model to another.

This specification was heavily based on the INSPIRE Address Representation data type. It is noteworthy that if an Address is provided using the detailed breakdown suggested by the properties for this class, then it will be INSPIRE-conformant. To this very granular set of properties, we add two further properties:

- full address (the complete address as a formatted string)
- addressID (a unique identifier for the address).

The first of these allows publishers to simply provide the complete Address as one string, with or without formatting. This is analogous to vCard's label property.

The addressID is part of the INSPIRE guidelines and provides a hook that can be used to link the Address to an alternative representation, such as vCard or OASIS xAL.

This class belongs to Core Location Vocabulary

description.en: The name of a geographic area that groups Addresses.

usage.en: This would typically be part of a city, a neighbourhood or village, e.g. Montmartre. Address area is not an administrative unit.

rawTags.definition-en: The name of a geographic area that groups Addresses.
rawTags.usageNote-en: This would typically be part of a city, a neighbourhood or village, e.g. Montmartre. Address area is not an administrative unit.

description.en: A globally unique identifier for each instance of an Address.

usage.en:
The concept of adding a globally unique identifier for each instance of an address is a crucial part of the INSPIRE data spec. A number of EU countries have already implemented an ID (a UUID) in their Address Register/gazetteer, among them Denmark. OASIS xAL also includes an address identifier. It is the address Identifier that allows an address to be represented in a format other than INSPIRE whilst remaining conformant to the Core Vocabulary.

The INSPIRE method of representing addresses is very detailed, designed primarily for use in databases of addresses. Whilst data that is published in full conformance with the INSPIRE data structure can be made available using theCore Location Vocabulary the reverse is not true since the Core Vocabulary allows much greater flexibility.

Many datasets that include address data as one piece of information about something else are likely to have that data in simpler formats. These might be tailored to the specific need of the dataset, follow a national norm, or make use of a standard like vCard.

To provide maximum flexibility in the Core Vocabulary, whilst remaining interoperable with INSPIRE Address Guidelines (which EU Member States are obliged to use), the Core Location Vocabulary provides the extra property of full address and makes use of INSPIRE's addressID.

rawTags.definition-en: A globally unique identifier for each instance of an Address.
rawTags.usageNote-en:
The concept of adding a globally unique identifier for each instance of an address is a crucial part of the INSPIRE data spec. A number of EU countries have already implemented an ID (a UUID) in their Address Register/gazetteer, among them Denmark. OASIS xAL also includes an address identifier. It is the address Identifier that allows an address to be represented in a format other than INSPIRE whilst remaining conformant to the Core Vocabulary.

The INSPIRE method of representing addresses is very detailed, designed primarily for use in databases of addresses. Whilst data that is published in full conformance with the INSPIRE data structure can be made available using theCore Location Vocabulary the reverse is not true since the Core Vocabulary allows much greater flexibility.

Many datasets that include address data as one piece of information about something else are likely to have that data in simpler formats. These might be tailored to the specific need of the dataset, follow a national norm, or make use of a standard like vCard.

To provide maximum flexibility in the Core Vocabulary, whilst remaining interoperable with INSPIRE Address Guidelines (which EU Member States are obliged to use), the Core Location Vocabulary provides the extra property of full address and makes use of INSPIRE's addressID.

description.en: The name of the uppermost level of the address, almost always a country.

usage.en: Best practice is to use the ISO 3166-1 code but if this is inappropriate for the context, country names should be provided in a consistent manner to reduce ambiguity. For example, either write 'France' or 'FRA' consistently throughout the dataset and avoid mixing the two. The Country controlled vocabulary from the Publications Office can be reused for this.

rawTags.definition-en: The name of the uppermost level of the address, almost always a country.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Best practice is to use the ISO 3166-1 code but if this is inappropriate for the context, country names should be provided in a consistent manner to reduce ambiguity. For example, either write 'France' or 'FRA' consistently throughout the dataset and avoid mixing the two. The Country controlled vocabulary from the Publications Office can be reused for this.

description.en: The name of a secondary level/region of the address, usually a county, state or other such area that typically encompasses several localities.

usage.en: Values could be a region or province, more granular than level 1.

rawTags.definition-en: The name of a secondary level/region of the address, usually a county, state or other such area that typically encompasses several localities.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Values could be a region or province, more granular than level 1.

description.en: The complete address written as a string.

usage.en: Use of this property is recommended as it will not suffer any misunderstandings that might arise through the breaking up of an address into its component parts. This property is analogous to vCard's label property but with two important differences: (1) formatting is not assumed so that, unlike vCard label, it may not be suitable to print this on an address label, (2) vCard's label property has a domain of vCard Address; the fullAddress property has no such restriction. An example of a full address is "Champ de Mars, 5 Avenue Anatole France, 75007 Paris, France".

rawTags.definition-en: The complete address written as a string.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Use of this property is recommended as it will not suffer any misunderstandings that might arise through the breaking up of an address into its component parts. This property is analogous to vCard's label property but with two important differences: (1) formatting is not assumed so that, unlike vCard label, it may not be suitable to print this on an address label, (2) vCard's label property has a domain of vCard Address; the fullAddress property has no such restriction. An example of a full address is "Champ de Mars, 5 Avenue Anatole France, 75007 Paris, France".

description.en: A number or sequence of characters that uniquely identifies the locator within the relevant scope.

usage.en: In simpler terms, this is the building number, apartment number, etc. For an address such as "Flat 3, 17 Bridge Street", the locator is "flat 3, 17".

rawTags.definition-en: A number or sequence of characters that uniquely identifies the locator within the relevant scope.
rawTags.usageNote-en: In simpler terms, this is the building number, apartment number, etc. For an address such as "Flat 3, 17 Bridge Street", the locator is "flat 3, 17".

description.en: Proper noun(s) applied to the real world entity identified by the locator. The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.

usage.en:
The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.

The key difference between a locator designator and a locator name is that the latter is a proper name and is unlikely to include digits. For example, "Shumann, Berlaymont" is a meeting room within the European Commission headquarters for which locator name is more appropriate than locator.

rawTags.usageNote-en:
The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.

The key difference between a locator designator and a locator name is that the latter is a proper name and is unlikely to include digits. For example, "Shumann, Berlaymont" is a meeting room within the European Commission headquarters for which locator name is more appropriate than locator.
rawTags.definition-en: Proper noun(s) applied to the real world entity identified by the locator. The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.

description.en: A location designator for a postal delivery point at a post office, usually a number.

usage.en: INSPIRE's name for this is "postalDeliveryIdentifier" for which it uses the locator designator property with a type attribute of that name. This vocabulary separates out the Post Office Box for greater independence of technology. An example post office box number is "9383".

rawTags.definition-en: A location designator for a postal delivery point at a post office, usually a number.
rawTags.usageNote-en: INSPIRE's name for this is "postalDeliveryIdentifier" for which it uses the locator designator property with a type attribute of that name. This vocabulary separates out the Post Office Box for greater independence of technology. An example post office box number is "9383".

description.en: The code created and maintained for postal purposes to identify a subdivision of addresses and postal delivery points.

usage.en: Post codes are common elements in many countries' postal address systems. One of the many post codes of Paris is for example "75000".

rawTags.definition-en: The code created and maintained for postal purposes to identify a subdivision of addresses and postal delivery points.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Post codes are common elements in many countries' postal address systems. One of the many post codes of Paris is for example "75000".

description.en: A name created and maintained for postal purposes to identify a subdivision of addresses and postal delivery points.

usage.en: Usually a city, for example "Paris".

rawTags.definition-en: A name created and maintained for postal purposes to identify a subdivision of addresses and postal delivery points.
rawTags.usageNote-en: Usually a city, for example "Paris".

description.en: The name of a passage or way through from one location to another.

usage.en: A thoroughfare is usually a street, but it might be a waterway or some other feature. For example, "Avenue des Champs-Élysées".

rawTags.definition-en: The name of a passage or way through from one location to another.
rawTags.usageNote-en: A thoroughfare is usually a street, but it might be a waterway or some other feature. For example, "Avenue des Champs-Élysées".

description.en: An event which resulted in a major change to an Organization such as a merger or complete restructuring.

usage.en: It is intended for situations where the resulting Organization is sufficiently distinct from the original Organizations that it has a distinct identity and distinct URI.

rawTags.definition-en: An event which resulted in a major change to an Organization such as a merger or complete restructuring.
rawTags.usageNote-en: It is intended for situations where the resulting Organization is sufficiently distinct from the original Organizations that it has a distinct identity and distinct URI.

description.en: A piece of legislation or a policy document that prompted the change.

usage.en: The property hasFormalFramework links a Change Event or Foundation Event to a piece of legislation or a policy document that prompted the change.

rawTags.definition-en: A piece of legislation or a policy document that prompted the change.
rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The property hasFormalFramework links a Change Event or Foundation Event to a piece of legislation or a policy document that prompted the change.

description.en: A textual explanation of the event.

rawTags.definition-en: A textual explanation of the event.

description.en: The Organization that existed before the change.

usage.en: Although the Foundation Event class is defined as a subclass of Change Event, it is inappropriate to use the original organization property with the Foundation Event class.

rawTags.definition-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The Organization that existed before the change.
rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=Although the Foundation Event class is defined as a subclass of Change Event, it is inappropriate to use the original organization property with the Foundation Event class.

description.en: This property links a Change Event or a Foundation Event to the Organization that resulted from it.

rawTags.definition-en: This property links a Change Event or a Foundation Event to the Organization that resulted from it.

description.en: The time instant when the state of the organisation update was terminated.

rawTags.definition-en: The time instant when the state of the organisation update was terminated.

description.en: The time instant when the state of the organisation update was initiated.

rawTags.definition-en: The time instant when the state of the organisation update was initiated.

description.en: A collection of people organized together into a community or other social, commercial or political structure. The group has some common purpose or reason for existence which goes beyond the set of people belonging to it and can act as an Agent. Organizations are often decomposable into hierarchical structures.

rawTags.definition-en: A collection of people organized together into a community or other social, commercial or political structure. The group has some common purpose or reason for existence which goes beyond the set of people belonging to it and can act as an Agent. Organizations are often decomposable into hierarchical structures.

description.en: Represents hierarchical containment of Organizations or OrganizationalUnits; indicates an organization which is a sub-part or child of this organization.

rawTags.definition-en: Represents hierarchical containment of Organizations or OrganizationalUnits; indicates an organization which is a sub-part or child of this organization.

description.en: Represents hierarchical containment of Organizations or OrganizationalUnits; indicates an Organization which contains this Organization.

rawTags.definition-en: Represents hierarchical containment of Organizations or OrganizationalUnits; indicates an Organization which contains this Organization.

description.en: A subdivision of Organization which is part of this Organization.

usage.en: The existence of an Organizational Unit depends on the Parent Organization, which means that it can only exist in the scope of the Parent Organization and not on its own.

rawTags.definition-en: A subdivision of Organization which is part of this Organization.
rawTags.usageNote-en: The existence of an Organizational Unit depends on the Parent Organization, which means that it can only exist in the scope of the Parent Organization and not on its own.

description.en: The Public Organisation of which the Organizational Unit is an operational department.

usage.en: Organizations typically comprise many departments, units, teams etc. Each of these is modelled in the CPOV as a unit that is linked from the parent Organization with hasUnit and to the parent with unitOf.

rawTags.definition-en: NOTE$ea_notes=The Public Organisation of which the Organizational Unit is an operational department.
rawTags.usageNote-en: NOTE$ea_notes=Organizations typically comprise many departments, units, teams etc. Each of these is modelled in the CPOV as a unit that is linked from the parent Organization with hasUnit and to the parent with unitOf.

description.en: A self-contained collection of information in a readable format.

usage.en: In alignment with FOAF, there is no distinction between physical and electronic documents, or between copies of a work and the abstraction those copies embody.

rawTags.definition-en: A self-contained collection of information in a readable format.
rawTags.usageNote-en: In alignment with FOAF, there is no distinction between physical and electronic documents, or between copies of a work and the abstraction those copies embody.

description.en: An identifiable geographic place or named place.

rawTags.definition-en: An identifiable geographic place or named place.

description.en: The text data type is a combination of a string and a language identifier.

usage.en:
It is useful for names and descriptions that are available in multiple languages. Where this is so, each version of the data should be included and each one associated with the relevant language identifier. RFC 3066 provides a commonly used set of identifiers for natural languages. This is the set recognised by UN/CEFACT and XML Schema.
Languages are represented by two character codes, optionally followed by a locale definition such as "de" meaning German and "de-at" meaning "German as spoken in Austria."

rawTags.definition-en: The text data type is a combination of a string and a language identifier.
rawTags.usageNote-en:
It is useful for names and descriptions that are available in multiple languages. Where this is so, each version of the data should be included and each one associated with the relevant language identifier. RFC 3066 provides a commonly used set of identifiers for natural languages. This is the set recognised by UN/CEFACT and XML Schema.
Languages are represented by two character codes, optionally followed by a locale definition such as "de" meaning German and "de-at" meaning "German as spoken in Austria."

description.en: The class of literal values, eg. textual strings and integers.

rawTags.definition-en: The class of literal values, eg. textual strings and integers.

description.en: anyURI represents an Internationalized Resource Identifier Reference (IRI).  An anyURI value can be absolute or relative, and may have an optional fragment identifier (i.e., it may be an IRI Reference).

usage.en: This type should be used when the value fulfills the role of an IRI, as defined in [RFC 3987] or its successor(s) in the IETF Standards Track.

rawTags.definition-en: anyURI represents an Internationalized Resource Identifier Reference (IRI).  An anyURI value can be absolute or relative, and may have an optional fragment identifier (i.e., it may be an IRI Reference).
rawTags.usageNote-en: This type should be used when the value fulfills the role of an IRI, as defined in [RFC 3987] or its successor(s) in the IETF Standards Track.

description.en: Date represents top-open intervals of exactly one day in length on the timelines of dateTime, beginning on the beginning moment of each day, up to but not including the beginning moment of the next day).  For non-timezoned values, the top-open intervals disjointly cover the non-timezoned timeline, one per day.  For timezoned values, the intervals begin at every minute and therefore overlap.

rawTags.definition-en: Date represents top-open intervals of exactly one day in length on the timelines of dateTime, beginning on the beginning moment of each day, up to but not including the beginning moment of the next day).  For non-timezoned values, the top-open intervals disjointly cover the non-timezoned timeline, one per day.  For timezoned values, the intervals begin at every minute and therefore overlap.

description.en: An idea or notion; a unit of thought.

rawTags.definition-en: An idea or notion; a unit of thought.

description.en: dateTime represents instants of time, optionally marked with a particular time zone offset.  Values representing the same instant but having different time zone offsets are equal but not identical.

rawTags.definition-en: dateTime represents instants of time, optionally marked with a particular time zone offset.  Values representing the same instant but having different time zone offsets are equal but not identical.
